content:
• Thursday, June 5, 2014
  • MY

    Ming Yang +9% on approval for planned Chinese wind power project

    • Ming Yang Wind Power (NYSE:MY) +9.1% AH on news it obtainedÂ approval to develop and operate a 300 MW offshore wind power project in China's Jiangsu province.
    • MY says it expects to leverage the opportunity deliver its wind turbine generators as a solution for offshore wind power projects in China and beyond.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:22 PM

  • After Hour Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5:15 p.m.: MY +6.9%. CMTL +4.6%. REDF +2.9%. ENSV +2.7%. PAY +2.7%.
    • Top losers, as of 5:15 p.m.: RALY -20.2%. SEAC -11.3%. CIDM -10.3%. DMND -9.1%. ARWR -4.2%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:35 PM | 1 Comment
  • RMGN

    RMG Networks soars; SA Pro sees potential multi-bagger

    • In an article embargoed until 5AM ET Friday, SA Pro author BuyTheDip, SellTheRip argues RMG Networks (RMGN +16.1%) is set to deliver strong organic revenue growth and Q/Q margin improvement over the rest of 2014 following a rough Q1 report.
    • The author thinks balance sheet concerns are overblown in light of management's efforts to address them, and declares shares trade "well below comparable multiples, private takeover valuation, and normalized earnings power."
     
     
     
     
    | 5:22 PM | 1 Comment
  • RALY

    Rally Software does the opposite on soft revenue guidance

    • Though Rally Software (NYSE:RALY) beat FQ1 estimates and posted nearly in-line revenue, it expects FQ2 revenue of $20.2M-$20.8M (just 2%-5% Y/Y growth) and FY15 (ends Jan. '15) revenue of $87M-$90M (17%-21% growth), below consensus estimates of $22.5M and $92.3M.
    • EPS guidance is a little better: Rally expects FQ2 EPS of -$0.39 to -$0.42 and FY15 EPS of -$1.31 to -$1.36 vs. consensus estimates of -$0.42 and -$1.57.
    • The provider of cloud-based software development tools says it "struggled slightly in selling new seats to new customers," as large growth in quote-carrying headcount caused "some execution delay."
    • Canaccord's recent remarks about the growing pains often faced by enterprise software companies (in reference to Splunk) appear relevant.
    • GAAP opex +27% Y/Y to $22.6M. Paid seats +6% Q/Q and +23% Y/Y to ~226K.
    • RALY -18.2% AH. FQ1 results, PR, CFO commentary (.pdf)
     
     
     
     
    | 5:01 PM | 1 Comment
  • PAY

    VeriFone offers strong top-line guidance, plans job cuts

    • VeriFone (NYSE:PAY) expects FQ3 revenue of $455M-$460M and EPS of $0.33-$0.34 vs. a consensus of $453.8M and $0.37. FY14 guidance is for revenue of $1.825B-$1.835B and EPS of $1.42-$1.44 vs. a consensus of $1.8B and $1.43.
    • The company plans to lower headcount by ~500 jobs (~10% of its workforce) by the end of calendar 2014.
    • Gross margin fell 100 bps Y/Y in FQ2 to 41%. R&D spend +20.2% Y/Y, sales/marketing +21.3%, G&A +11.4%. CEO Paul Galant has made new product development a priority following years of relatively low investment.
    • EMEA revenue (41% of total) +10.3% Y/Y, North America +2.7%, Latin America -2.3%, Asia-Pac +36%.
    • Systems revenue (62% of total) +5.1%, a notable improvement from FQ1's -7.3%. Services revenue (38% of total) +17.4% vs. +19% in FQ1.
    • PAY +3.5% AH. FQ2 results, PR.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:39 PM
  • RALY

    Rally Software beats by $0.23, misses on revenue

    • Rally Software (NYSE:RALY): Q1 EPS of -$0.27 beats by $0.23.
    • Revenue of $19.43M (+21.1% Y/Y) misses by $0.16M.
    • Shares -21.03% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:33 PM
  • DMND

    Higher tree nut costs a hinderance at Diamond Foods

    • Snack segment sales of $114.3M (+9.6% Y/Y)
    • Nuts segment sales of $76.6M (-5%)
    • An increase in walnut prices during quarter hit Nuts segment to the tune of $2.2M.
    • Gross margin of 23.6% (up 20 bps)
    • Adjusted EBITDA of $23.5M (+1.5%)
    • Outlook: Despite headwinds of boosted tree nut costs, company expects to realize an increase in Adjusted EBITDA Y/Y.
    • CC at 4:30 ET
    • DMNDÂ -7%Â AH
    • Previously: Diamond Foods misses by $0.06, misses on revenue
     
     
     
     
    | 4:23 PM
  • VHC

    VirnetX jumps after USPTO denies RPX petitions

    • An RPX request (on behalf of client Apple) for a USPTO review for several VirnetX (VHC +6.8%) patents has been denied. (h/t Tom Shaughnessy)
    • The USPTO calls RPX's petitions "time-barred," given they were filed more than a year after Apple (deemed the "real party" in the dispute) was served with an infringement complaint.
    • In March, VirnetX was assigned a 0.98% royalty rate on certain Apple products by an Eastern Texas district court; Apple, not surprisingly, has appealed the verdict. VirnetX shares initially shot higher on the ruling, but gradually gave back their gains.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:18 PM | 1 Comment
  • CMTL

    Comtech Telecommunications beats by $0.13, beats on revenue

    • Comtech Telecommunications (NASDAQ:CMTL): FQ3 EPS of $0.32 beats by $0.13.
    • Revenue of $88.91M (+27.3% Y/Y) beats by $11.41M.
    • Shares +2.15% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:17 PM
  • SEAC

    SeaChange International misses by $0.19, misses on revenue

    • SeaChange International (NASDAQ:SEAC): Q1 EPS of -$0.22 misses by $0.19.
    • Revenue of $24.33M (-31.6% Y/Y) misses by $6.54M.
    • Shares -12.47% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:12 PM
  • PAY

    VeriFone Systems beats by $0.05, beats on revenue

    • VeriFone Systems (NYSE:PAY): FQ2 EPS of $0.37 beats by $0.05.
    • Non GAAP Revenue of $467M (+8.7% Y/Y) beats by $23.58M.
    • Shares +3.85% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:03 PM
  • JOY

    Joy Global +6.7% on earnings beat, guidance

    • Joy Global (JOY +6.7%) powers to its highs of the day after reporting FQ2 earnings that reflected the global mining equipment slowdown but topped low expectations and backing its FY 2014 guidance.
    • JOY said in its earnings conference call that its deal with Mining Technologies will add to its underground hard rock mining growth prospects.
    • Joy also sees growth in the oil sands market, particularly in Canada, which it said represents the largest unconventional source of oil production over the next 20 years.
    • Global mining peers also are higher: CAT +2.6%, VALE +1%, BHP +0.7%, RIO +0.7%.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:59 PM
  • BRLI

    BioReference Labs up big after earnings report

    • Shares of BioReference Laboratories (BRLI +20.6%) jump on a 5x surge in volume in response to its fiscal Q2 earnings report.
    • Net revenues: $201.4M (+14.1%); operating income: $18.9M (-8.7%); net income: $10.3M (-8.8%); EPS: $0.37 (-9.8%); cash & equiv: $24.5M (+36.1%).
    • Revenue/patient: $84.18 (-0.9%).
     
     
     
     
    | 3:53 PM
  • SMSI

    Smith Micro +35.9% on Amazon phone rumor

    • A rumor that Smith Micro's (NASDAQ:SMSI) 3D animation tech is used in Amazon's upcoming smartphone has led the microcap's shares to fly higher.
    • Yesterday, Amazon announced a June 18 event that's expected to involve the launch of a smartphone capable of showing (via 4 front-facing cameras) 3D images.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:53 PM | 2 Comments
  • NBGGY

    Periphery gets biggest boost from ECB

    • Europe's Stoxx 50 gainedÂ nearly 1%Â in wake of today's ECB rate cut and move towards QE, but the periphery outperformed, with the strongest market being the one furthest out - AthensÂ +2.8%.
    • The Global X FTSE Greece 20 ETF (GREK +3.4%) is now up 40% Y/Y.
    • National Bank of Greece (NBG +6.5%) also enjoyed an upgrade to Buy from Deutsche Bank.
    • Emerging European markets: Turkey (TUR +3.5%) and Poland (EPOL +1.6%).
    • ETFs: GUR, ESR
    • Previously: Negative rates not the end of moves for the ECB
     
     
     
     
    | 3:49 PM | 5 Comments
  • BTU

    Coal stocks rebound, as Stifel makes the case

    • Gains in coal stocks (NYSEARCA:KOL) have gone up in smoke thanks to new rules from the EPA that would limit its use as a fuel for power generation, but shares are bouncing a bit today as Stifel analysts make the case for coal as a worthwhile investment.
    • Coal’s power market share dropped from 49% to 39% while the natural gas share rose from 19% to 27% from 2005 to 2013, but Stifel argues that much of the investment case for U.S. coal centers on its ability to step in as a low-cost, reliable Plan B if Plan A (gas and renewables) falls short, and the cold weather-impacted Q1 offered a glimpse of what this might look like.
    • Stifel favor exposure to U.S. coal mining firms in low-cost regions including the Illinois Basin, Powder River Basin and Northern Appalachia; these include Buy-rated Peabody Energy (BTU +2.2%), Cloud Peak Energy (CLD +2.2%) and Consol (CNX +3.6%).
    • Also: ANR +5.6%, WLT +4.8%, ACI +3.4%, WLB +1.2%.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:26 PM | 11 Comments
  • HK

    Halcon Resources' price target upped to $9 from $7 at Wunderlich

    • Halcon Resources (HK +3.8%) is maintained at Buy but with a $9 price target, raised from $7, at Wunderlich, which notes shares have climbed due to continued growth of HK's Tuscaloosa Marine Shale acreage position and initial activity.
    • Upcoming initial well results and the potential for a Tuscaloosa joint venture could begin to show the value in the play while also allowing HK to boost its production and liquidity positions, the firm says, adding that it believes these potential catalysts are not priced into the stock.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:58 PM | 2 Comments
  • DB

    Deutsche warns investors over currency investigation

    • “The extent of Deutsche Bank’s (DB -3.2%) financial exposure to these matters could be material, and Deutsche Bank’s reputation may suffer material harm as a result," says the bank in the prospectus related to its capital raise.
    • No criminal charges have been filed over currency market manipulation, but more than two dozen traders have been fired across a number of banks. What's more, prosecutors - having wrung a guilty plea and massive fine out of Credit Suisse and about to do the same with BNP Paribas - have now gotten the taste of blood, and may have found they like it.
    • Deutsche today raised €8.5B in an equity offering and plans to raise another €6.75B through a rights offering expected to be completed this month.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:51 PM | 2 Comments
  • NIHD

    NII Holdings +21.3% on strong volume

    • Volatile NII Holdings (NASDAQ:NIHD) is flying higher on volume (4.9M shares) that has already exceeded its 3-month average (4.8M).
    • No news has hit the wire to explain the move. NII exec Cristina Ruiz de Velasco recently issued comments (picked up by Mexican media) calling for new measures to boost telecom competition in a market dominated by America Movil - a telecom reform bill was passed last December - but Nextel's views on the matter (and the Mexican government's) are well-known.
    • Nearly 27% of the float was shorted as of May 15. Shares still -80% YTD amid major liquidity concerns.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:32 PM | 3 Comments

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Top 10 Gainers: UNXL +32%. DHRM +21%. BZC +20%. CIEN +19%. VTL +19%. CLDX +17%. BRLI +17%. AGTC +15%. VTUS +14%. XNPT +14%.
    • Top 10 Losers: LTM-OLD -12%. RCAP -10%. ZNGA -10%. HRTX -9%. RAD -9%. EONC -8%. LIVE -8%. WH-OLD -8%. AMBT -8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:49 PM | 2 Comments
  • S

    Sprint, T-Mobile turn negative as Street mulls merger reports

    • With worries about the DOJ/FCC's willingness to approve a Sprint (S -2.6%)/T-Mobile (TMUS -2%) merger still running high, shares of both carriers are now lower following reports stating they've largely agreed to the terms of cash/stock deal that would value T-Mobile at ~$40/share.
    • T-Mobile is now 16% below the rumored acquisition price. A deal would reportedly require Sprint to pay ~$16B in cash, issue a similar amount of stock, and assume $9B worth of net debt.
    • Sprint already had $26.6B in net debt at the end of Q1, and has since used its receivables to land a $1.3B credit facility.
    • The WSJ reports Sprint would pay T-Mobile a $1B+ breakup fee consisting of cash and other assets if the deal is shot down. T-Mobile received a $4B breakup fee from AT&T ($3B in cash) in 2011 after regulators derailed their planned merger.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:17 PM
  • AMZN

    Whole Foods up on buyout chatter

    • Whole Foods (WFM +4.5%) gains amid unconfirmed reports the company is being acquired.
      •  
       
     
     
     
     
    | 12:13 PM | 8 Comments
  • ASMB

    Trading activity picks up for Ventrus

    • Shares of pico cap Ventrus Biosciences (VTUS +19.5%) jump on 3x higher volume. Today's action follows a breakout on May 29 when prices popped 23% on 14-fold surge in volume.
    • Traders appear to be taking positions before the company's pre-IND meeting with the FDA on June 19 where the parties will discuss guidance regarding an approval path for Dolizem (diltiazem hydrochloride cream) as a treatment for anal fissures. Based on a positive outcome of the meeting, Ventrus plans to file an NDA in 2H 2014 with an expected PDUFA date about a year later.
    • On February 12, shares cratered 61% on turnover of 18M shares after the firm reported that Dolizem failed to outperform placebo in a second Phase 3 trial. In the first Phase 3, the product did demonstrate a statistically significant improvement in pain versus placebo.
    • The company's previously-announced merger with Assembly Pharmaceuticals will close around July 10. The name of the combined firm will be Assembly Biosciences trading under the ticker "ASMB."
     
     
     
     
    | 12:01 PM
  • KEYW

    KEYW +7.8% after chairman/CEO buys more shares

    • With KEYW Holding's (KEYW) shares remaining over 50% below their 52-week high, chairman/CEO Leonard Moodispaw bought 15K shares yesterday at $10.01.
    • The purchase comes two weeks after Moodispaw, 70, bought 15K shares at $10.87.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:39 AM | 2 Comments
  • TSLA

    SolarCity higher after striking panel supply deal

    • Norway's REC will supply 100MW-240MW of solar panels to SolarCity (SCTY +3.8%) over a 12-month period starting in Q4. The panels will be installed across SolarCity's 15-state coverage area.
    • The announcement comes a day after SolarCity fell modestly in response to the DOC's imposition of fresh tariffs on Chinese solar panel imports - a move that could increase SolarCity's panel costs.
    • In May, SolarCity said it expects to deploy 500MW-550MW of systems in 2014, and 900MW-1GW of systems in 2015.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:32 AM | 4 Comments
  • ZNGA

    Zynga -9.8% following Mattrick presentation

    • Zynga (NASDAQ:ZNGA) has plunged below $3 on volume (50.9M shares) that's already nearly 2x a daily average of 28.2M.
    • CEO Don Mattrick held a Q&A session yesterday afternoon at a BofA/Merrill conference (transcript). Though generally upbeat, he admitted Zynga could be affected by summer seasonality, and that near-term EBITDA margins remain pressured by product investments (e.g. bringing FarmVille to mobile).
    • Mattrick also: 1) Noted Zynga's headcount had fallen to 1,800 as of January from 2,650 at the time of his hiring; the NaturalMotion deal added 270 employees. 2) Declares Zynga's audience has "stabilized" after many quarters of steep DAU/MAU losses. 3) Suggests he's open to using part of Zynga's $1.1B+ cash balance on new acquisitions/partnerships.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:22 AM | 9 Comments
  • SODA

    More weakness at SodaStream with PepsiCo front quiet

    • Shares of SodaStream (SODA -1.5%) slip lower to etch out new 52-week lows.
    • Though traders have been looking for it, there hasn't been any news on a timely partnership with PepsiCo that could help the company challenge products put out by Keurig Green Mountain and Coca-Cola.
    • During SodaStream's last earnings call, CEO Daniel Birnbaum struck an indie tone that has unnerved some analysts.
    • SodaStream Q1 CCÂ transcript
     
     
     
     
    | 11:05 AM | 3 Comments
  • CCJ

    RBC takes an axe to uranium price outlook, sees continued surplus

    • RBC cuts its outlook for uranium prices over the next several years as it concludes the market will remain in surplus through 2020.
    • RBC believes Japanese reactor restarts could result in a recovery in uranium prices to $40/lb. in late 2014 or early 2015, but thinks the price is likely to be capped at that level until the market begins to tighten; the firm predicts only four Japanese reactors will restart this year with 28 - slightly more than half the current fleet - eventually restarting.
    • Spot prices recently dropped below $30 as supply remains well ahead of demand since the Fukushima disaster.
    • RBC cuts its price target for industry leader Cameco (CCJ -2.5%), seeing shares rangebound between $18-$27.
    • URZ -3.3%, UUUU -2.5%, URRE -1.5%, UEC -1.1%, USU -0.9%, DNN flat, URG flat.
    • ETFs: URA, NLR, NUCL.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:54 AM | 16 Comments

  • Initial reaction following ECB is reversed

    • Interesting action in the markets finds most doing a complete reversal of their knee-jerk response following the ECB rate cut and early part of the Draghi press conference (where he seemed to be laying the groundwork for QE).
    • The euro (FXE) has turned around more than 100 pips and gone green on the session. Germany's DAX (EWG) and London's FTSE (EWU) have turned lower, though the periphery (EWI, EWP) is hanging on to gains. The 10-year Treasury yield - which jumped to 2.64% - has returned to 2.59%. TLTÂ -0.1%, TBTÂ +0.2%
    • Showing little reaction in the immediate aftermath of the ECB action, gold is now moving noticeably higher at $1,253 per ounce. GLDÂ +0.75%
    • Previously: Negative rates not the end of moves for the ECB
     
     
     
     
    | 10:35 AM | 10 Comments
  • UNXL

    UniPixel +34.9% after announcing operational update call

    • UniPixel (NASDAQ:UNXL) says it will hold a CC at 4:30PM ET on June 25 to discuss the progress it has made towards "achieving a reliable, high-volume, roll-to-roll production process" for its InTouch sensor films.
    • After jumping yesterday in the absence of news, shares are now up 50% from Tuesday's close.
    • Worth noting: 1) Shares are still down over 80% from an April '13 high of $41.42. 2) 3.9M shares (38% of the float) were shorted as of May 15, though that's down considerably from the 5.8M shorted as of Dec. 31.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:31 AM | 5 Comments
  • LULU

    Analysis: Sell-off in Lululemon done

    • Sterne Agee moves off its bearish stance on Lululemon (LULU), raising shares to Neutral from Underperform.
    • The investment firm thinks the stock found a bottom in the lower $40s and will recover as the retailer's execution gets back on track.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:24 AM | 1 Comment
  • PSMT

    PriceSmart opens new warehouse club in Honduras

    • PriceSmart (PSMT -0.4%) announces it opened a new warehouse club in Honduras.
    • The launch will be the third in the nation and brings the total number of warehouses in operation to 33.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:18 AM
  • INFN

    Infinera, Finisar, JDS, others higher following Ciena's earnings

    • Ciena is flying higher after beating FQ2 estimates and issuing above-consensus FQ3 guidance. As is its custom, rival Infinera (INFN +2.2%) is heading in the same direction as Ciena, as are component vendors Finisar (FNSR +3.6%) and JDS Uniphase (JDSU +1.7%).
    • Other gainers include deep packet inspection hardware vendors Allot (ALLT +5.5%) and Procera (PKT +3%), access/metro equipment provider Adtran (ADTN +3%), network processor developer Cavium (CAVM +1.2%), and carrier Wi-Fi hardware vendor Ruckus (RKUS +1.8%). An upbeat Oppenheimer note could be contributing to Allot's gains.
    • The rally comes a few days after Ciena and other industry names fell due to a Jefferies report stating AT&T has slashed wireline capex ahead of the DirecTV deal's closing and the full rollout of its giant Domain 2.0 SDN/NFV initiative.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:12 AM
  • RATE

    Bankrate gains after RBC upgrade

    • Buy the dip in Bankrate (RATE +3.9%), says RBC Capital upgrading to Outperform with $21 price target. The recent decline in the shares leaves them undervalued amid a more stable outlook for the company's insurance and credit card units.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:06 AM
  • SYNA

    Synaptics higher on Feltl upgrade

    • A week after reports emerged Synaptics (SYNA +1.2%) is set to buy a 55% stake in Renesas' LCD driver IC unit, Feltl has upgraded shares to Strong Buy.
    • Street commentary on Synaptics' rumored deal has been quite positive. Chardan has argued Synaptics could take share from Himax at Samsung and Chinese OEMs, and Needham has praised the company's "platform" approach to capacitive touch (involving touch controllers, display drivers, and fingerprint sensors).
    • Shares +30% YTD, and not far from a 52-week high of $69.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:55 AM
  • RAD

    Guidance trips up Rite Aid

    • Shares of Rite Aid (RAD -11.8%) slump after guidance from the company disappoints.
    • The drugstore operator sees FY14 EPS of $0.30-$0.40 vs. $0.31-$0.42 prior and $0.39 consensus.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:52 AM | 7 Comments
  • FARO

    Faro jumps on Needham upgrade

    • Needham has upgraded Faro Technologies (FARO +4.8%) to Buy. Its PT is at $50.
    • The industrial measurement/imaging system vendor plunged in April following a slight Q1 revenue miss. Shares are still down 23% YTD.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:44 AM
  • MRVL

    Marvell -4.1% after 22.5M-share block trade is priced

    • A 22.5M-share Marvell (NASDAQ:MRVL) block trade has been priced at $15.50, well below a Wednesday close of $16.02.
    • The most likely sellers are KKR (disclosed a 6.8% stake in December, reportedly wants a sale), David Einhorn (owned ~39M shares at the end of Q1), and co-founders Sehat Sutardja and Weili Dai.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:28 AM | 4 Comments
  • MVIS

    MicroVision +27.8% on smartphone partnership

    • MicroVision (NASDAQ:MVIS) is partnering with an unnammed "major global consumer electronics brand" to create a smartphone display engine that leverages the company's PicoP tech. The companies are targeting a potential 2H15 product launch.
    • The partner is said to be a Fortune Global 500 company: Apple and Samsung are among the companies on the list.
    • MicroVision also says it's "ramping up for volume production of key components" for its pico projector module deal with Sony (referred to as "another global electronics brand"), which it announced last year.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:21 AM

  • Premarket Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: MVIS +20%. HALO +16%. CIEN +15%. SSLT +7%. CPRX +6%. UNXL +5%.
    • Losers: VRA -11%. RAD -10%. RCAP -8%. NVAX -7%. PVH -6%. SNN -6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:12 AM | 1 Comment
  • NEWL

    NewLead +40%, gets restraining order stopping issuance of shares

    • NewLead Holdings (NASDAQ:NEWL) +40.3% premarket after announcing it was granted a temporary restraining order against Ironridge Global IV prohibiting the further issuance of common shares in payment of dividends on series A preference shares.
    • NEWL says Ironridge is no longer entitled to conversions of the shares and will not accept further funds from Ironridge.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:56 AM | 2 Comments
  • VRA

    Freefall for Vera Bradley as patterns become tired

    • Shares of Vera Bradley (NASDAQ:VRA) crumble after coming off of a premarket trading halt following a weak earnings report.
    • Demand for the company's trademark patterned products has fallen off considerably both in stores and through other distribution channels.
    • VRA -17.9% premarket
     
     
     
     
    | 8:49 AM | 1 Comment

  • Negative rates not the end of moves for the ECB

    • Seemingly setting the stage for QE, Mario Draghi - beginning his post-ECB policy meeting press conference - says the central bank wii stop sterilizing its previous bond purchases made under the Securities Market Program (SMP).
    • "The governing council is committed to using unconventional measures if there is too long a period of too low inflation." Among the moves are targeted LTROs and purchases of asset-backed securities.
    • The Stoxx 50 (FEZ) isÂ ahead 1.5%Â now, and the euroÂ -0.7%.
    • ETFs: FXE, VGK, EUO, FEZ, ERO, IEV, EPV, EZU, HEDJ, DRR, FEU, FEP, UPV, ULE, EUFX, ADRU, URR, FEEU, EURL, EURZ, FIEU, DBEU
    • Also with their tail in the air are U.S. futures, the S&P 500 (SPY)Â up 0.4%Â after being flat earlier, and U.S. Treasury yields - the 10-year jumps to 2.64% from 2.57% earlier.
    • ETFs: SPY, SH, TBT, TLT, SSO, SDS, VOO, IVV, SPXU, UPRO, TMV, SPXL, RSP, TBF, RWL, EPS, EDV, TMF, TTT, ZROZ, SBND, TLH, BXUB, DLBS, VGLT, UBT, TLO, SFLA, SPLX, BXUC, TENZ, LBND, TYBS, SPUU, DLBL
    • Previously: ECB goes negative
     
     
     
     
    | 8:42 AM | 32 Comments
  • EQNR

    Norway deal expected to ease path for Statoil's Johan Sverdrup project

    • Statoil (STO) +2.1% premarket after Norway's government and opposition lawmakers reach a compromise to start electrification of three North Sea oil fields by 2022, which should reduce the risk of further delays in starting the giant Johan Sverdrup project.
    • A majority in parliament had demanded that STO and other energy companies include three more fields in their power plan for Sverdrup as part of broader efforts to cut greenhouse gas emissions; the companies would have needed to start laying cables to the other fields in Sverdrup’s start-up phase, which STO said would delay the 2019 output start and lead to losses of as much as $3.3B.
    • STO says the compromise means full electrification will not happen in the first phase, as the second phase will start some time in 2022.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:18 AM
  • Z

    Zillow gets 2nd downgrade of the week

    • It's another valuation call, with SunTrust pulling its Buy rating after Zillow's (NASDAQ:Z) big run higher.
    • "While we remain very bullish on the long term prospects for the company ... we think the market has accounted for some of the opportunity, making the stock expensive in the short term to our coverage universe at 11.2x 2015 revenues and 55x 2015 EBITDA."
    • SharesÂ -1.6%Â premarket
    • Previously: Zillow slips after downgrade at Pacific Crest
